reading_mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have １回, ２回, ３回, or even １００回 if you're into that sort of thing.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

The reading for 金 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. Makes sense since this is a single kanji with hiragana attached. Here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You've saved up a ton of money. With it you're going to buy something awesome. Then, suddenly someone hits you in the knees with a bat. Now you have to spend all your <vocabulary>money</vocabulary> buying a <reading>cane</reading> (かね). Sucks for you :(
This has two readings, but luckily you learned one of them when you learned the kanji, and the other one when you learned the word 他. The two readings are usually interchangeable, too.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that 一 is shortened (as it often is) to いっ.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 生 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who has been in charge of you your <vocabulary>whole life</vocabulary>? The <reading>sho</reading>gun (しょう). He owns everyone and that's how it will stay for your <vocabulary>entire life</vocabulary>.
This uses on'yomi for all the kanji, so you should be good to go here!

The word comes from 三日 and 月, but the readings are slightly different. There's no small つ in the reading for 三日, and you need to rendaku 月, all to make it easier to pronounce. Try reading it aloud yourself to see what I mean!
To write the character づ, type "du" on your keyboard.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you can guess that it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've learned that reading, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

You know this word means <vocabulary>to go up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to rise</vocabulary>. Imagine just rising into the air, sort of floating up all of a sudden. What would you say? You'd probably scream "<ja><reading>Ah</reading></ja>!" (あ) the moment you started to go up. You know, out of surprise. Going up? Ah!

That い on the end is your clue that the reading is different, and you can forget about the readings you learned for each kanji. This is a native Japanese word, and the kanji were assigned to it based on the meaning alone. That means you just have to memorize the reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you see that someone's <vocabulary>good at</vocabulary> something, you say, "<reading>Ooh</reading>, <reading>my</reading> (うまい)!" at the top of your lungs. Try it! Think of something that impresses you and say "ooh my!" out loud.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Let's use a mnemonic to remember the reading of the kanji:

You know it means <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> so instead of using a <reading>sa</reading>w (さ) to cut down the tree, you decide to let it come to you. It has to come down all by itself. Picture yourself placing a saw at the foot of a tree then sitting back and waiting for it to drop itself at your knees. (This could actually work, don't you judge my methods!)

The reading for this word is all kun'yomi despite being jukugo. Just think of sketchy things going on in the downtown, just like how there's sketchy kun'yomi readings for this word. You should know both the kun'yomi readings from the previous level, though, so if you do you know the reading for this word as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Who always said not to mix your white and red socks in the laundry? That would be your <reading>Ma</reading> (ま).
Since you already know the vocab word 今 (read いま), you should be able to read this word as well.

The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word 今. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this. Just watch out because rendaku makes くさ become ぐさ.
This is a jukugo word, which means it uses on'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You already know those, so you should be good to go!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あ part but let's include the う as well for this one. Who do you want <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary> more than anyone? Think about it. Then, imagine meeting them. The first thing they do is grab your arm and pinch it. You yell out "<reading>OW</reading>!" (あう) and they laugh and run away.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You have your body. It's nice - looking good! What would really mess up your body? It would be a <reading>car raider</reading> (からだ). I'm talking about a dude who is a raider of some kind driving a car. If he runs into your body, you're done for, so watch out for the car raider. 

Of course, this mnemonic is only meant to get you close to the reading. Hopefully it is close enough to get you to the actual reading, からだ.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>physical strength</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stamina</vocabulary> are tied together with a <reading>tie</reading> <reading>lock</reading> (たいりょく). That's a lock made of ties that ties your strength and stamina up together, making it much easier to pace yourself.
The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.

This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 何 and the on'yomi reading for 人. Since 何 and 人 both have two readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

<vocabulary>How many people</vocabulary> eat <reading>naan</reading> at <reading>Nin</reading>tendo (なんにん)? You've been tasked with counting everybody eating naan for lunch at Nintendo, so you better get started!
The reading is the kun'yomi なん for 何 and the rendaku'd on'yomi reading for 千 (ぜん) combined together. It's one of those weird words that mixes the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings.

This is a jukugo word with a slightly unique reading, where the first kanji uses the kun'yomi reading and the second uses the on'yomi reading. You've seen these readings before, so you should be able to read this alright.
The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

<vocabulary>How many days</vocabulary> does it take you to bake a <reading>naan</reading> <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (なんにち)? It's not easy to make a Nietzsche entirely out of naan, so I wonder how many days it would take.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but 何 actually uses the kun'yomi reading here! And since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading:

<vocabulary>What month</vocabulary> gives you <reading>naan</reading> <reading>guts</reading> (なんがつ)? It's the month you eat so much naan that even your guts turn into naan! But <vocabulary>which month</vocabulary> was it again?

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the つく portion. In order to do that let's think about something that you're going to make. Imagine something really awesome. You complete it and look at your masterpiece. It's amazing. You realize right then and there that it's <reading>too coo</reading>l (つく) for the general public to see. You proceed to smash it. It's way too cool.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since both 文 and 作 have two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which ones to use:

You can't stop writing <vocabulary>composition</vocabulary>s about <reading>sack</reading>s 'n' <reading>bun</reading>s (さくぶん). You're obsessed with them. You've been writing <vocabulary>essay</vocabulary> after essay about sacks 'n' buns. Stop <vocabulary>writing</vocabulary> about sacks 'n' buns!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's <reading>Ani</reading> (あに), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You have a ton of <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary> where you live. This creates heat. With this sunlight heat you're able to make your favorite food in the world: <reading>hickory</reading> (ひかり) smoked bacon. Mmm, taste that delicious bacon.

When a vocab is a single kanji plus some okurigana (hiragana stuck on the end of kanji) it's almost always going to be the kun'yomi reading. This is one of two kun'yomi readings you'll be learning for the kanji 入. As long as you know that this vocab means <vocabulary>to insert</vocabulary>, you can use that to remember the reading as well. 

Imagine inserting your hand into a hole and an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) flies out, screaming: "<reading>い</reading>!" This is something that happens every time you insert your hand into something: an eagle comes out. You don't know why.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The part of the word that you have to learn how to read is the だ portion. Remember how someone was going to sue you for trying <vocabulary>to take out</vocabulary> way too much? Well, that someone is your <reading>Da</reading>d (だ)! Your own Dad is going to sue you if you keep taking out way too much stuff, so you better stop!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you try <vocabulary>to understand</vocabulary> something, you just start screaming "<reading>WAAAAAAAAAHHHH</reading>" (わ). It helps you focus and concentrate on what you’re trying to understand, to the dismay of everyone around you. WAAAAAAAAAHHHH.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you think of the word "same" think <vocabulary>same</vocabulary> <reading>owner</reading> (おな). You're looking at a restaurant that has a sign that says, "New owners!" However, when you walk in you see it's the same terrible owner you remember from before. What a liar.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

On the <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary>, you once ate two entire <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts. <reading>Gee, two</reading> (どうじつ) on the same day? How did that feel?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have a bag of walnuts that you're bringing to a friend's house but you trip and drop them all on the ground. You shout, "<reading>Mah Wa</reading>lnuts! (まわ)" as they start <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary> around you on the ground. Picture your walnuts going around you, getting all dirty.

While words that are made up of a single kanji usually take the kun'yomi reading, this one takes the on'yomi reading. Luckily, this is the same reading you learned with the kanji, so it shouldn't be too hard to remember.
The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji making it easy to remember!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Think of something that is <vocabulary>many</vocabulary>. Doesn't matter what it is as long as you imagine a ridiculous number of them. Many of them. So many that they start avalanching into you and crushing you. The last thing you yell is "<reading>おお</reading>!!!" as you get smushed.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Generally</vocabulary>, it's a bad idea to <reading>dye</reading> your <reading>tie</reading>s (だいたい). The tie police isn't a big fan of it, and you wouldn't wanna get arrested!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Did you know that there's a <vocabulary>monumental work</vocabulary> about a <reading>tie</reading> <reading>sack</reading> (たいさく)? It's a <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary> about a magic sack that produces tie after tie after tie after tie... A bit like The Magic Porridge Pot, but with a sack and ties instead.
The reading for 声 is ごえ (rendaku'd version of the reading you know: こえ). The reading for 大 is the kun'yomi reading, like with the word 大きい (おおきい). Just imagine a loud voice saying "おお！."

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 大 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your <vocabulary>university</vocabulary> is best known for its <reading>dye</reading> <reading>gawk</reading>ing (だいがく). It's a sport in which you gawk at dye, and your university is the best at it! Other universities might be known for their football or basketball teams, but yours is the best at dye gawking.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the まな part to learn this word's reading. Think about a class you're taking. It's a manners class, and you're there <vocabulary>to learn</vocabulary> <reading>manner</reading>s (まな). Imagine this study of manners and imagine yourself practicing it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

Your favorite <vocabulary>handicraft</vocabulary> is making <reading>こう</reading>いち <reading>sack</reading>s (さく). They're sacks that look exactly like こういち, and you're incredibly good at making them. Soon, the Tofugu offices will be decorated all over with your こういち sacks.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell <reading>"OH. Toe? TOE!"</reading> (おとうと) as you realize what's going on.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You have to remember the あ portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>? It is the first answer, <reading>A</reading> (あ).

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the あ portion. 

When your guess turns out <vocabulary>to be right</vocabulary>, you can't help but shout, "<reading>Ah</reading>! (あ)" That "Ah" is your victory cry.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 文 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

All the great works of <vocabulary>literature</vocabulary> are about <reading>bun</reading>s (ぶん). That's the subtle thread running through all literature: buns.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the にち reading of 日 becomes にっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:

The best place for <vocabulary>sunlight</vocabulary> in Japan is <reading>Nikkō</reading> (にっこう). It's one of Japan's most beautiful national parks, and the perfect spot to catch some rays!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

The <vocabulary>moonlight</vocabulary> brings out a strange creature known as a <reading>Geck</reading>-<reading>こう</reading>いち (げっこう), which are geckos with the head of こういち. Imagine a swarm of them all crawling out of their crevices once the moon comes out.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for this word is pretty strange. It changes depending on the type of verb form you use (it's a pesky exception verb). To remember the reading of this word, here's a mnemonic: 

"I want you <vocabulary>to come</vocabulary> to the <reading>coo</reading>l (く) side, Luke," says Darth Vader.
"What?" replies Luke.

Just replace this line into the famous line from Star Wars. Say it out loud. Do the Vader voice. It'll help you to remember.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 月 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Next month</vocabulary> is when <reading>rye</reading> <reading>gets</reading> (らいげつ) into your diet! You're going to eat only rye bread and drink only rye beer for all of next month. Bet you can't wait!
Since this word is made up of a single kanji it uses the kun'yomi reading. You've already learned this reading with the kanji, though, so you should be able to read this.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 止める, so you should be able to read it already!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for 毎 is what you'd expect. The reading for 年 is the kun'yomi reading, though. So, use your knowledge of the vocab 年 to help yourself to remember the reading for this word. You'll need to remember that the reading for this word is strange to get it into that brain of yours.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 日 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

<vocabulary>Every day</vocabulary> you watch your favorite program, <reading>My</reading> <reading>Nietzsche</reading> (まいにち). It's a <vocabulary>daily</vocabulary> cartoon about Nietzsche and his life, which you follow religiously. Oh how much you love Nietzsche.
This word has the on'yomi reading for 毎 plus the kun'yomi reading for 月. That makes it まいつき.

The readings for these kanji are the kun'yomi readings. With 毛 you should have learned this reading via the vocab word in the previous level. With 糸 it's actually the main reading for the kanji, so you should already know it.

The readings for this word are strange. Both use the kun'yomi readings - 虫 uses the reading you learned with the kanji, so that's easy. The 毛 part is like the vocab word 毛 you learned in the previous lesson.

The reading for this word consists of the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>水</kanji> and the kun'yomi reading of <kanji>色</kanji>. For 水 you'll know this reading via your vocab studies. For 色 it just so happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji.
Both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 生まれる. Just drop the る off the end and you have your reading!

You have to remember the う part of this word to be able to read it. It's the same as 生まれる, so that could help if you've learned that word already. If not, just imagine yourself giving birth, but not to a baby. Instead, it's an <reading>u</reading>ni (う) you're delivering. Luckily, uni aren't fully formed with their spikes at birth so it shouldn't be a problem. Ooof! What a relief!

This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). That being said, in level 4 you learned about the vocab readings for these separate words, so use that knowledge to remember the reading for this word as well.
If you know the kun'yomi readings of both of these kanji you should be okay. You have two separate single-kanji words put together by a の. That's why it's the kun'yomi reading - they're separate.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

As a human (we think), you have a lot of <vocabulary>skin</vocabulary>. But sometimes a normal shower isn't enough to wash all that skin. What do you do when you can't fit all your skin in the shower or the tub? You get your skin cleaned at the <reading>ca</reading>r <reading>wa</reading>sh, of course!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

In the sky, you are the ruler. You are known as "The <reading>soarer</reading>!" (そら). Imagine your theme song and make sure it includes "soarer of the sky" or something awesome like that.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji with 立つ, so you should be good to go!

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: 

"Everyone, we have rice! <reading>Come</reading> (こめ) and get it!"
Since this word is made up of a single kanji with nothing attached it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read this.

If you want <vocabulary>to think</vocabulary>, the best way to do so is to do the <reading>conga</reading> (かんが). Imagine yourself doing the conga and thinking away. You're so inspired! The thoughts are flowing as freely as your sweet, slow dance moves.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Luckily for you, this word uses the on'yomi reading that you learned even though it's a single kanji all on its own. So, you should know it already!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. This is the reading you learned with the kanji, though, so enjoy.
The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

You have to remember the い portion. To remember い we use the word "eagle." 

You want <vocabulary>to go</vocabulary> somewhere (anywhere!) but you can't. An <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) blocks your path. You try to go forward and it opens its wings and bites at you. You try to go back and it jumps at you. There's nowhere for you to go with this eagle standing there.

The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji (the kun'yomi reading). So as long as you know that you should be able to read this word as well.

This word has two different meanings and each one has its own reading.

When it's used for <vocabulary>corner</vocabulary>s, the reading is かど. Just picture a deck of <reading>card</reading>s (かど). What's the most important part of the card? The corner! The corners are where the numbers are. Now tape those cards into all the corners of your house. Why? Because it's artsy!

And the second meaning and reading pair is easy — <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary> and かく, which you already know from the kanji!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

To remember the reading い we use the word "eagle." 

You're trying <vocabulary>to say</vocabulary> something, but every time you try to say anything an <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) swoops down and pecks at your face then flies away. Just imagine yourself saying tiny bits of words, then an eagle crashing down on your face. Then, you wait in silence. Nothing happens. You try to say something again, and the eagle swoops down on you again.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. This happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji, too, so don't feel like you're stuck in a valley of despair or anything. Rejoice!
Reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

You have to remember the はし portion. Think of yourself running. It's nice. As you run, though, you notice the ground changing into something weird and mushy. Everything is turning into <reading>hash</reading> (はし) browns. You start to get sucked in, and soon you can't run anymore. Smell the hash browns and taste them too. What a terrible run this was.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The readings are double kun'yomi. The kun'yomi reading is what you learned with 里 already, though you'll have to pull out the 心 vocab reading to remember it all. Not only that, the 心 gets rendaku'd here making it ごころ. Make sure you watch out for that.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji you would normally think it uses the kun'yomi reading. Not this word, though. It still uses the on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji. Don't confuse this one with お金, though. That one uses kun'yomi which you know because it has a hiragana attached.
This word uses the on'yomi for 金 and the kun'yomi for 玉. If you know the readings of your kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.
